thread.title: MPs celebrate 60th anniversary of the EU… and here’s how many turned up
thread.title_full: MPs celebrate 60th anniversary of the EU… and here’s how many turned up

title: MPs celebrate 60th anniversary of the EU… and here’s how many turned up

locations.name: north east of the united kingdom

text:
MPs celebrate 60th anniversary of the EU… and here’s how many turned up MPs celebrate 60th anniversary of the EU… and here’s how many turned up ONLY a handful of MPs today turned up to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the European Union’s founding treaty. PUBLISHED: 12:30, Tue, Mar 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 12:45, Tue, Mar 21, 2017 PARLIAMENT.TV Just three MPs spoke in the poorly-attended debate 
In a poorly-attended debate, just three MPs spoke as Brussels prepares to remember the signing of the Treaty of Rome later this week. 
On Saturday, top eurocrats will mark the 60th anniversary of the agreement between six founding countries to create the European Economic Community, the forerunner of the EU. 
But there appeared to be little enthusiasm in Parliament this morning for the bloc’s upcoming celebrations in the wake of last summer’s Brexit vote. Related articles Minister told to remind Germany of WW2 debt before Brexit talks 
The SNP’s Stephen Gethins, who secured the Westminster Hall debate, urged MPs to remember the “unprecedented success” of the EU since the signing of the Treaty of Rome on March 25, 1957. 
Referring to the Leave vote on June 23 last year, he said: “At this time of uncertainty in terms of our relationship with our European partners, I think it's easy to lose sight of the major contribution EU membership has for us all. 
“The bloc is by no means perfect - building co-operation between 28 independent and sovereign member states is always going to be difficult. And the necessary compromises will need to be made and sometimes those are a bit messy. 
“But overall we're better with it and overall we're in a better place because of the signing of the Treaty of Rome 60 years ago.” PARLIAMENT.TV There was little sign of enthusiasm for the Treaty of Rome celebrations PARLIAMENT.TV The SNP's Europe spokesman Stephen Gethins urged MPs to remember the EU's 'unprecedented success' PARLIAMENT.TV Brexit minister Robin Walker responded for the Government Overall we're in a better place because of the signing of the Treaty of Rome 60 years ago SNP's Stephen Gethins 
Fellow SNP MP Kirsten Oswald spoke to praise Mr Gethins’“incredibly powerful speech about the benefits of the EU”. 
And Brexit minister Robin Walker completed just a trio of MPs to speak in the short debate, having been required to respond on behalf of the Government. 
In a message to the SNP over their attempts to split the UK apart, the Tory MP said: “At this momentous time it is more important than ever we face the future together, taking forward our shared interest in the UK being an open, successful, global nation into the future. 
“So as member states of the EU meet this week to discuss the history and future of the European project, we wish our EU partners well. 
“The UK will no longer be an EU member state but it will be a close ally and a friend. 
“A strong partnership between the UK and the EU is in the interests of both and we congratulate all the EU's members on this important anniversary.” Brexit: Results of how the UK voted Mon, March 20, 2017 Much of the North East of the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union including Sunderland, Gateshead, Darlington, Durham, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, Stockton, Redcar and Cleveland, North Tyneside and South Tyneside, and Northumberland Getty Images 1 of 8 GREAT YARMOUTH: The town of Great Yarmouth on the East Coast of England voted by 72% to leave the European Union. 
SNP MP Brendan MacNeil was refused permission to speak by chair Nadine Dorries having turned up late for the debate before seeking to make an intervention. 
Westminster Hall, a second debating venue to the main House of Commons chamber, had been much better attended for a preceding debate on the relationship between the DVLA and private car parking companies. 
Theresa May will not be attending an EU summit in the Italian capital this weekend to mark the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome. Related articles
